name: Kepler-180
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-180 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-180 is a star with 1.037 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.06 times its radius. It is located 2315.15 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-180 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-180 b

Kepler-180 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.11 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 13.82 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-180.

The mass of Kepler-180 b is 2.55 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-180 b is 1.5 that of Earth. At 2.55 Earth masses, Kepler-180 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-180 c

Kepler-180 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.23 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 41.89 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-180.

The mass of Kepler-180 c is 13.60 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-180 c is 3.01 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-180 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-180, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
